Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 7 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, and 10 edges A->C, A->F, B->F, B->C, B->G, C->G, C->F, D->F, D->E, F->G.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents customer satisfaction, B represents product quality, C represents customer loyalty, D represents marketing campaign effectiveness, E represents sales revenue, F represents customer retention and G represents business growth.
Background.data_info: For those with product quality being poor, the probability of customer retention being low is 0.0977. The probability of product quality being poor and customer retention being low is 0.0214. The probability of product quality being high and customer retention being high is 0.7665.

Instruction: Consider the probability of necessity (PN) of product quality on customer retention.
Question: Given that product quality was high and customer retention was high, what is the upper bound of the probability of the customer retention would have been low if the product quality had been poor?
given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Customer satisfaction has a direct effect on customer loyalty. Customer satisfaction has a direct effect on customer retention. Product quality has a direct effect on customer retention. Product quality has a direct effect on customer loyalty. Product quality has a direct effect on business growth. Customer loyalty has a direct effect on business growth. Customer loyalty has a direct effect on customer retention. Marketing campaign effectiveness has a direct effect on customer retention. Marketing campaign effectiveness has a direct effect on sales revenue. Customer retention has a direct effect on business growth.
